thread.title: MSU women battle Illini to 1-1 draw in double OT
thread.title_full: MSU women battle Illini to 1-1 draw in double OT

title: MSU women battle Illini to 1-1 draw in double OT
text:
MSU women battle Illini to 1-1 draw in double OT Lansing State Journal 11:07 p.m. EDT October 8, 2015 491207181 (Photo: GETTY IMAGES) 
EAST LANSING — The Michigan State women’s soccer team outlasted a wild ride Thursday evening in its 1-1 double overtime draw with Illinois to earn one more point towards its quest to get to the Big Ten tournament. 
Sophomore Morgan McKerchie tested the Fighting Illini backline within the first two minutes, firing off a shot that was stopped by sophomore goalkeeper Claire Wheatley. 
After a corner kick in the fourth minute, senior defender Alexandra Gjonaj sent the ball curling into the back of the Illini net to put her team up 1-0. 
The offensive momentum continued to be generated in the Spartan front-third as freshman Lexy Warner made her own attempt on goal. 
The Illini’s potent offense, coming into the game ranked third in the Big Ten for shots and fourth in goals scored, was denied by the Spartan defense, which blocked six shots in the contest. The speed and footwork of the MSU midfield, led by McKerchie, senior Sarah Kovan, and freshman Michaela Kovacs, thwarted the passing lanes of the Illini. 
Michigan State head coach Tom Saxton credited McKerchie, whose presence on the field played a noticeable impact, for opening up the offense. 
“The midfield is doing a much better job of when we gain possession, getting us out of pressure and opening up the game,” Saxton said. “I will single out Morgan McKerchie as she has found her form. It took her awhile, but it’s helped us a lot because she’s calm and technical.” 
Saxton noted the presence Kovan and Kovacs at the midfield position as well. 
Coming into the second half, play continued to intensify as both teams battled to put a point on the scoreboard, with the Spartans showing a slight upper-hand in ball possession in the final minutes. 
In the final seconds of the game, Jannelle Flaws fired a shot towards the Spartan net only to be blocked. Teammate Nicole Breece followed up with her own shot on goal that was saved by MSU senior goalkeeper Gabrielle Gauruder. In a flurry around the box, players collided as many thought time had expired. 
After deliberating with one another, the referees determined that there was a foul in the box. Flaws buried the penalty kick in the back right corner of the net to send the game into overtime. 
“I think we defended and outplayed [Illinois] 80 percent of the game,” Gjonaj said. “We shut down Janelle Flaws, and they had very good players on their side. I think we played very well together coming back from [the final call].” 
Gauruder would deny the Illini for the remaining 20 minutes, finishing out the shutout with seven saves. The Spartans had several chances at gaining the advantage, battling the full 110 minutes for the fifth game to be sent into overtime this season. 
Saxton said that despite the wildness of the outcome, he was glad of the composure the Spartans maintained. 
“I thought the team had a great performance,” Saxton said. “Illinois is a good team, but I thought it was a pretty even game. I told my team after the game that [the final seconds of the second half] was one of the craziest things I’ve seen in my 25 years of coaching, and yet the way they caught their breath and responded in overtime was fantastic.” 
Looking to defend DeMartin once more, the Spartans will host Northwestern at 1 p.m. Sunday. 
- MSU Athletic Communications Read or Share this story: http://on.lsj.com/1Rx173Q TOP VIDEOS
